page.title: 02BELCHAMP ST. PAUL
page.content: {Belchamp St. Paul}is the main village in the area. It's history can be traced back at least to Norman times;{Paul's Hall,}behind the church occupies the site of the{Domesday Manor. The name 'Belchamp' comes from several sources. In saxon times it meant 'a settlement on a hill',or a 'hamlet of belcs or cruck houses',and after 1066 the normans continued to call it Belchamp, meaning 'beautiful fields'.{St.Pauls Cathedral, London, owned land in the village and eventually paid for the church to be built and the village became known as Belchamp St. Paul. The rights of the cathedral have now passed to the chapel at{Windsor Castle. Some say that during the Dark and Middle Ages the village was called Baalchamp.
